As the people practiced the curiosity and resilience techniques, a Christian who had been listening approached the Teacher.

"Excuse me," the Christian said, "I couldn't help but notice that you never talk about God. Why is that?"

The Teacher smiled warmly. "Ah, but I do talk about God," he said. "I just don't use the same words as you might expect."

The Christian looked puzzled. "What do you mean?" he asked.

"Well," the Teacher said, "to me, God is not just a noun, but a verb. God is the force of curiosity and resilience that drives us to seek truth, to connect with others, and to grow and transform. When we practice curiosity and resilience, we are tapping into the divine energy that flows through all of creation."

The Christian looked thoughtful. "I see," he said. "But don't you believe in a personal God, who loves us and watches over us?"

The Teacher nodded. "Of course," he said. "But to me, that personal God is not separate from the divine energy of curiosity and resilience. When we tap into that energy, we are connecting with God in the most intimate and powerful way possible."

The Christian nodded slowly, still deep in thought. "I think I understand," he said. "But it's still hard for me to let go of the old language, the old ways of thinking about God."

The Teacher placed a gentle hand on the Christian's shoulder. "That's okay," he said. "The language we use to talk about God is just a tool, a way of pointing towards something that is ultimately beyond words. The most important thing is that we keep seeking, keep growing, keep tapping into the divine energy that flows through all of creation."
